twitter_threads.topic: How to get your first 10 customers
tweets: Your first 10 customers are the hardest. Here's the exact playbook I wish I had when starting out (thread):

Step 1: Define your ICP in ONE sentence.

"I help [person] solve [problem] so they can [outcome]."

If you can't fill in those blanks clearly, you're not ready to sell yet. Go narrower.

Step 2: Have 20 conversations BEFORE you pitch.

Ask: "What's the most frustrating part of [problem] for you?"

You're not selling. You're learning the exact words your customers use. That's your future copy.

Step 3: Build ONE landing page.

- Headline (their problem)
- 3 benefits
- Social proof
- 1 CTA

A single focused page beats a 10-page site at this stage. Every time.

Step 4: Mine your warm network.

Former colleagues. LinkedIn connections. Community members. Alumni.

Send 50 personal messages. Expect 5-10 real conversations. That's where your first customers come from.

Step 5: Do things that don't scale.

Personally onboard every user. Check in at day 3, 7, 14. Fix problems fast.

These people become your evangelists.

twitter_threads.topic: AI marketing tools that actually work
tweets:
I've tested dozens of AI marketing tools in 2026.

Here's an honest take on what works, what's hype, and what solo founders actually need (thread):

Content generation tools are everywhere. ChatGPT, Claude, Jasper, Copy.ai.

The real difference? Context retention.

A tool that remembers your brand and ICP saves hours vs one that needs re-explaining every session.

Email tools: keep it simple.

You need 3 sequences:
- Welcome
- Nurture
- Re-engagement

That's it. ConvertKit free tier + Resend for transactional. Don't overcomplicate it.

Landing page builders: speed to publish matters most.

Your page will change 12 times in month one as you learn what converts. Pick a tool that gets you live in under an hour.

The big question: 6 separate tools or one platform?

For solo founders, consolidation wins. Less context switching. Data flows between features. One learning curve.

Your brain has limited RAM. Don't waste it on tab management.

Solo founder stack on a budget:

LaunchPilot $19/mo (content + pages + outreach)
ConvertKit free (email)
GA4 (analytics)

Covers 90% of what you need.

Launching soon? Here's the checklist I use for every product launch.

Save this thread -- you'll need it:

30 DAYS BEFORE:

- Define one measurable launch goal
- Lock in your ICP and positioning
- Build and publish your landing page
- Install analytics + conversion tracking
- Write all launch content in advance

2 WEEKS BEFORE:

- Join 3-5 communities where your audience hangs out
- Start sharing your build journey publicly
- Line up 10-15 early supporters for launch day
- Set up email welcome + onboarding sequences

LAUNCH DAY:

- Go live before 8am (their timezone)
- Message your inner circle first
- Post everywhere you prepared
- Reply to EVERY comment within 30 min
- Track metrics hourly -- amplify what works

POST-LAUNCH (30 days):

- Follow up personally with every signup
- Do 5-10 user interviews
- Ship top 3 requested features fast
- Double down on your best channel
- Set your next milestone: 10 → 50 → 100

The biggest launch mistake?

Treating it as one day instead of a 90-day process.

30 days prep. 1 week execution. 30 days follow-through.

linkedin_posts.content:
I spent 6 months building a product nobody asked for.

Then I spent 3 months building landing pages, writing cold emails, and posting on social media -- with zero customers to show for it.

Here's what I learned the hard way about getting your first 10 customers:

The problem wasn't my product. It was my process.

I was building in isolation. No customer conversations. No validation. No ICP definition. Just vibes and assumptions.

When I finally sat down and talked to 20 people in my target market, everything changed:

- I learned the exact words they used to describe their problem (instant copy improvement)
- I discovered 3 features I thought were important that nobody cared about
- I found 5 people who were willing to pay before I even finished building

The lesson: your first 10 customers come from conversations, not campaigns.

Talk to people. Listen to their words. Build what they need. Then reach out personally -- not with a mass email blast, but with a genuine message that shows you understand their problem.

It doesn't scale. That's the point.

Do things that don't scale until you've earned the right to automate.

If you're a solo founder working on getting your first customers, I wrote a complete step-by-step guide: https://launchpilot.marketing/blog/how-to-get-first-10-customers?utm_source=linkedin&utm_medium=organic&utm_campaign=launch_awareness

Hot take: most solo founders are using too many AI marketing tools.

I see this pattern constantly:

- ChatGPT for blog drafts
- Jasper for ad copy
- Buffer for social scheduling
- Mailchimp for emails
- Carrd for landing pages
- Apollo for outreach
- GA4 for analytics

That's 7 tools. 7 logins. 7 billing cycles. And you have to re-explain your brand, audience, and product in each one.

For a solo founder, context switching is the real productivity killer.

Every time you jump between tools, you lose focus. You re-enter the same information. You waste time on integration rather than execution.

The AI marketing tools that actually work for solo founders share three traits:

1. They retain context about your business across sessions
2. They let you go from idea to published output in minutes, not hours
3. They consolidate multiple functions so your data and brand voice stay consistent

You don't need the best email tool AND the best landing page builder AND the best content generator. You need one tool that does all three well enough to ship.

Perfect is the enemy of launched.

I wrote a full breakdown of the AI marketing tool landscape for solo founders -- what's real, what's hype, and how to build your stack at every budget level: https://launchpilot.marketing/blog/ai-marketing-tools-solo-founders?utm_source=linkedin&utm_medium=organic&utm_campaign=launch_awareness

Your launch will fail if you treat it as a single day.

The best launches I've seen (and run) follow a 30-7-30 framework:

30 days of preparation:
- Define one measurable goal (not "get users" -- something specific)
- Lock in your ICP and test your positioning on real people
- Write ALL launch content in advance (you'll be too stressed on launch day)
- Join communities and contribute value before you ever mention your product
- Line up 10-15 supporters who'll amplify on launch day

7 days of execution:
- Go live early morning in your audience's timezone
- Message your inner circle personally first
- Reply to every single comment and DM within 30 minutes
- Follow up personally with every new signup
- Post daily updates: milestones, learnings, user feedback

30 days of follow-through:
- Conduct 5-10 user interviews (signups, non-converters, and churned users)
- Ship your top 3 requested features fast
- Double down on your highest-converting channel
- Start building repeatable content: weekly blog + social + email
- Set your next milestone

The founders who "fail at launch" usually skip Phase 1 and Phase 3. They wing the preparation and ghost the follow-through.

Preparation and persistence beat hype every time.
